Comment: Fairly standard Sicilian Dragon lines ... A common favourite of mine, though if I'm honest it is because I am trying to get to know the line better as opposed to being particularly good at it.

Now I am preparing for a kingside attack -- this restricts my bishop on g7, and I am hoping the compensation can make it worthwhile!
h3 has minimised my kingside threats, but at the cost of dubious pawn structure for white. I now transfer my desire to controlling the center, preparing to play d5 whilst connecting my rooks

Releasing the pin whilst potentially allowing a future doubling of rooks -- need to be careful not to allow the c3 knight to become active -- looking after the b5 and e4 squares are now vital

This push was premature. The idea is there with good pressure aiming at the white king, but I need to be very careful about the vulnerability of the d6 rook -- after the pawn swaps I have both the queen and the rook attacking the d file. Playing Rf-d1 first would have been helpful
